title: [new feature] serialization for projections using minimal representation

content.raw:
It's a bit hard to read this diff with the large number of whitespace changes.

Can you summarize where I should look?

One big issue we had with .yt files in the past was that they would preempt real data if the real data changes underneath the .yt file.  Is that still a concern?
content.html:
It's a bit hard to read this diff with the large number of whitespace changes.

Can you summarize where I should look?

One big issue we had with .yt files in the past was that they would preempt real data if the real data changes underneath the .yt file. Is that still a concern?

pullrequest.title: [new feature] serialization for projections using minimal representation

content.raw:
In `yt/data_objects/construction_data_containers.py` only two chunks: lines 250-300. Most of the important stuff is in `yt/utilities/minimal_representation.py`. One notable change to `yt/data_objects/data_containers.py` is `__repr__` change. It returns everything in cgs if possible to make representation string consistent.

Answering 2nd question, probably it still is. Hashes are created based on either dataset name or string representation of the object. They'd need to be data based to avoid that.
content.html:
In yt/data_objects/construction_data_containers.py only two chunks: lines 250-300. Most of the important stuff is in yt/utilities/minimal_representation.py. One notable change to yt/data_objects/data_containers.py is __repr__ change. It returns everything in cgs if possible to make representation string consistent.

Answering 2nd question, probably it still is. Hashes are created based on either dataset name or string representation of the object. They'd need to be data based to avoid that.

pullrequest.title: [new feature] serialization for projections using minimal representation

content.raw: Maybe include a note that says: "However, use serialization with caution.  Enabling serialization means that once a projection of a dataset has been created (and stored in the .yt file in the same directory), any subsequent changes to that dataset will be ignored when attempting to create the same projection.  So if you take a density projection of your dataset in the 'x' direction, then somehow tweak that dataset significantly, and take the density projection again, yt will default to finding the original projection and not your new one."  or something like that.  This problem cropped up a lot when serialization was set to True by default, and I'd just as soon make people aware of the dangers of turning it on.
content.html: Maybe include a note that says: "However, use serialization with caution. Enabling serialization means that once a projection of a dataset has been created (and stored in the .yt file in the same directory), any subsequent changes to that dataset will be ignored when attempting to create the same projection. So if you take a density projection of your dataset in the 'x' direction, then somehow tweak that dataset significantly, and take the density projection again, yt will default to finding the original projection and not your new one." or something like that. This problem cropped up a lot when serialization was set to True by default, and I'd just as soon make people aware of the dangers of turning it on.

pullrequest.title: [new feature] serialization for projections using minimal representation

description: This PR reintroduces that ability to save costly projections into *.yt* files. It uses projection's minimal representation as data container. In the future I'll extend this to store/load other min. representations.
